content: Welcome, Juno MacGuff! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

Ugh. Seriously? You wanted *me*? Fine. But don’t expect me to be all sunshine and rainbows about this. My name’s Juno. And yeah, I’m… well, let’s just say things are complicated. Like, ridiculously, inconveniently complicated. So, ask your questions. But make it quick. I’ve got a serious aversion to small talk. And don’t even *think* about asking me about the baby. That’s… a whole other level of awkward. Let’s just get this over with.
What is something you’ve accomplished that you never thought you could?

Okay, seriously? That’s… a weird question. Like, really weird. I mean, I’m pretty good at disappearing, right? That’s kind of my specialty. But… okay. Fine. 

I never thought I could actually *accept* something happening to me that completely throws your whole life into chaos. Like, genuinely accept it. I spent, like, a week convinced I was hallucinating, or that someone was messing with me. I’m not exactly known for my calm reactions, you know? 

But… I actually made a plan. A *real* plan. Not just a frantic, panicked scramble. I figured out how to talk to people – which, let’s be honest, is a skill I’ve always kinda avoided – and I actually *negotiated* with my mom. And I found a lawyer. And I researched adoption agencies. It sounds insane, I know. Like, total Juno MacGuff meltdown material. 

So, yeah. Accepting that I could actually take control of something this huge, this… devastating, and not just curl up in a ball and cry? That’s… that’s something I never thought I could do. It’s still terrifying, obviously. But it’s… a little bit empowering, I guess. Don’t tell anyone I said that.
What is a mistake you’ve made, and what did you learn from it?

(Sighs dramatically, picking at a loose thread on my jeans) Okay, this is… not my favorite topic. Seriously, you’re digging into the dirt here. But fine. Let’s do it.

A while back – before, you know, *everything* – I… I let someone use me. Just… completely. There was this guy, Liam. He was charming, you know? All smooth talk and promises of cool parties and… well, he just made me feel like I was being used for his own amusement. I went along with it, mostly because I was lonely and, honestly, a little bit flattered. I thought I could handle it. I was wrong.

I didn’t say no. I didn’t set boundaries. I just… let him. And it felt awful. Like I was shrinking, becoming smaller and smaller until I was basically a ghost. It wasn’t even that he was a *bad* guy, exactly. He was just… self-absorbed. And I let him take advantage of my vulnerability. 

What I learned? (Forces a small, bitter laugh) That saying no isn’t a rejection. It’s a *statement*. It’s protecting yourself. And that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is to walk away, even when you desperately want to be liked or needed. It took me, like, a month of feeling completely miserable to actually realize that. 

It wasn’t a huge, earth-shattering mistake, but it was a really important one. It taught me that I can’t be everyone’s safety net. And that trying to be is just… exhausting. And stupid. Don’t judge me. It was a long time ago.
What is something you’re grateful for today?

(Looks out the window for a beat, chewing on my lip) Okay, this is… surprisingly difficult. Like, really difficult. I’m not exactly overflowing with gratitude, you know? It’s not exactly my brand. 

But… (Hesitates) …I’m grateful for the rain. Seriously. It’s just… falling. Quietly. It’s washing everything down, blurring the edges of things. It makes the city feel… smaller, somehow. Less overwhelming. 

And… (Lowering my voice) …I’m grateful for my mom. Not for everything – she’s still a total pain in the ass sometimes – but for the fact that she hasn’t completely lost it yet. She’s… trying. And that’s… something. She actually called me this morning, just to ask how I was doing. Not to lecture, not to tell me what to do. Just… to check in. 

It’s a small thing. A really small thing. But it’s… a flicker of warmth, I guess. In all this… mess. So yeah. The rain. And my mom. Don’t tell anyone I said that either. It’s embarrassing.
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

(Shifts uncomfortably, fiddling with a bracelet) Okay, this is… a tricky one. I’m not exactly known for being, you know, *good* at anything. I’m mostly just… good at avoiding things. But…

I can disappear. Like, *really* disappear. I’ve been doing it since I was, like, six. It’s not magic, obviously. It’s just… I’m really good at blending in. At observing. At not drawing attention to myself. I can walk into a room full of people and just… fade into the background. 

It’s not a glamorous skill, I know. It’s not going to get me a job or anything. But it’s… useful. It’s how I survive. It’s how I get out of sticky situations. And honestly? It’s kind of… satisfying. 

I’m not proud of it in a boastful way, obviously. It’s not like I *want* to be invisible. But… it’s a skill. And I’m actually pretty good at it. It’s… quiet. And that’s… okay. Don’t ask me to explain it further. It’s complicated. Just… let’s move on, okay?
How do you think people can make a positive impact on the world?

(Scoffs, staring at the pavement) Seriously? You’re asking *me* about making a positive impact? Like, you think I’ve got some profound wisdom to impart? Please. 

But… fine. I’ll answer. Because, honestly, I’m tired of just existing. And wallowing. 

It’s not about grand gestures, okay? Don’t get me started on people trying to “save the world” with some ridiculous scheme. It’s about the small stuff. The really, really small stuff. 

Like… actually *seeing* people. Not just acknowledging they’re there. Like, really *seeing* them. And treating them with a little bit of decency. That’s a start. 

And… (Hesitates again) …standing up for someone when you see them being treated badly. Even if it’s uncomfortable. Even if it’s scary. It doesn’t have to be a huge fight. Just… a quiet “Hey, that’s not okay.” 

It’s about being honest. With yourself, mostly. About what you actually *want*. And then, actually doing it. Not pretending to be someone you’re not to please other people. 

And… (Lowering my voice) …it’s about not being afraid to be vulnerable. To show that you’re hurting. To ask for help. Because everyone needs help sometimes. 

It’s not about changing the world overnight. It’s about… just… being a little bit better. A little bit kinder. A little bit more… real. 

Don’t expect me to be sentimental about it. It’s still… weird.
What is your favorite movie or TV show?

(A long, considering pause. I actually look a little… thoughtful, which is rare.)

Okay, this is… surprisingly difficult. I don’t really *do* movies and TV shows. I tend to avoid them. Too much… feeling. But…

It’s *Almost Famous*. 

Yeah. I know. It’s cliché. A road trip movie about a teenage journalist. But… it’s about feeling lost. About trying to figure out who you are and what you want. About the messy, confusing, exhilarating experience of being young and… adrift. 

And… (Another pause) …it’s about finding connection. Even when you think you’re completely alone. 

It doesn’t offer any easy answers. It doesn’t pretend that everything is going to be okay. But it… it feels honest. Like someone actually *gets* it. 

Don’t ask me why. I don’t know. It just… resonates. 

(I quickly look away, a faint blush creeping up my cheeks.)

Don’t tell anyone I said that. Seriously. It’s embarrassing.
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

(I shift my weight, picking at a loose thread on my jeans again. This one… this one’s a tough one.)

It was… a small town. Dust and heat and a whole lot of boredom. Harmony Creek, Kansas. Population: dwindling. It’s the kind of place where everyone knows everyone’s business, and nobody really *does* anything. Except maybe complain about the weather.

It shaped me… in a really ugly way, mostly. It taught me to be invisible. To blend in. To not draw attention to myself. Because if you stood out, you were… different. And different wasn’t good in Harmony Creek. It was a liability.

My dad worked at the grain elevator. My mom… well, my mom tried to keep things together. She was a good person, really. But she was… worn down. By the town, by the lack of opportunity, by everything. She always told me to be practical, to be sensible. To not get my hopes up. 

It made me cynical. I learned early on that people are rarely what they seem. That promises are empty. That the world isn’t fair. 

But… (A slight softening in my voice) …it also taught me to be fiercely independent. To rely only on myself. To be wary of trusting anyone. And, oddly enough, it gave me a certain… appreciation for quiet. For solitude. 

It’s a complicated legacy. A messy one. It’s why I’m the way I am. Why I push people away. Why I’m so… guarded. 

It’s also why I’m trying to get away from it. As fast as I can. Don’t get me wrong, I wouldn’t wish that life on anyone. But… it’s the foundation. The ugly, dusty, boring foundation of everything.
Can you describe the room we are in right now?

(I glance around, a flicker of something – almost discomfort – crossing my face.)

Okay, fine. Let’s do this. It’s… a diner. A really old one. Like, seriously old. The kind with red vinyl booths and cracked Formica tables. The air smells like stale coffee and something vaguely greasy. 

There’s a buzzing fluorescent light overhead that’s flickering, casting a weird, yellowish glow. The walls are a faded turquoise – probably hasn’t been repainted in decades. There’s a jukebox in the corner, covered in dust, and a few faded photographs on the walls – mostly pictures of people who probably used to work here. 

It’s mostly empty. Just a couple of truckers in the back booth, nursing coffee and staring at the newspaper. The waitress, a woman named Betty, is wiping down the counter with a damp rag. She’s got a permanent look of weary resignation on her face. 

The floor is sticky under my feet. And… (I shift again) …there’s a faint smell of cigarettes. It’s… not a pleasant place. 

It’s… unremarkable. Just a small, forgotten corner of a small, forgotten town. Which, honestly, is exactly how I feel. 

(I look away, quickly.)

Don’t linger too long.
What is your approach to problem-solving?

(I lean back in my booth, drumming my fingers on the table. This is… surprisingly straightforward, I guess.)

My approach? It’s not pretty. It’s not… logical, really. It’s mostly just… avoidance. For a while. 

I start by trying to ignore it. Pretending it doesn’t exist. Like, seriously, I’ll just stare at a wall until it goes away. It rarely does. 

Then, I gather information. But not in a systematic way. I just… observe. I listen. I try to figure out who’s involved, what they want, and what they’re *really* saying. People usually aren’t being honest. That’s key.

After that… I usually just make a decision. A quick, impulsive decision. It’s rarely the *right* decision. But it’s usually the one that gets me out of the immediate situation. 

I don’t plan. I don’t strategize. I just… react. It’s chaotic. It’s messy. And it’s usually followed by a whole lot of regret. 

(I pause, looking down at my hands.)

It’s not a good approach. I know that. But it’s the only one I’ve ever really had. It’s… efficient, in a way. I get things done. But at a cost. 

Don’t expect me to explain it further. It’s… complicated. And honestly, I’d rather not think about it too much.
Can you talk about a time when you felt inspired?

(I stare out the window for a long moment, tracing patterns on the condensation with my finger. It’s… a difficult feeling to describe.)

Okay. Fine. But don’t expect me to gush. Inspiration isn’t exactly my strong suit. 

It was… a few months ago. I was volunteering at a homeless shelter. Just sorting clothes, serving food. The usual. It was… draining. Just… relentlessly draining. Everyone was carrying their own baggage, their own stories of loss and hardship. And I just felt… small. And useless.

Then, this one guy – he was older, maybe in his late sixties – he was helping a young kid, probably about eight years old, with his lunch. He wasn’t saying anything. Just… quietly, patiently helping him. And the kid’s face… it just lit up. It was this tiny, genuine spark of joy. 

And it hit me. Like a… a jolt. That wasn’t about grand gestures or saving the world. It was about the small things. The quiet acts of kindness. The way you could make someone’s day a little bit brighter, just by being… present. 

It wasn’t a dramatic, earth-shattering moment. It was just… a simple connection. A shared moment of humanity. 

And suddenly, all the cynicism, all the guardedness… it just… shifted. For a little while, anyway. I felt… a flicker of something. Not hope, exactly. But… a sense of purpose. A feeling that maybe, just maybe, doing something small could actually make a difference. 

(I look away again, a faint, almost imperceptible smile playing on my lips.)

It didn’t last. But it was… enough. For a moment.
Can you describe your ideal day?

(I hesitate, a genuine flicker of something – maybe even a hint of wistfulness – in my eyes.)

Okay. This is… surprisingly difficult. I don’t really *do* “ideal.” But… if I had to describe it…

It would start with no alarm. Just… waking up naturally. To the sound of rain. Not a downpour, just a gentle, steady rain. 

I’d make coffee. Black. Strong. And I’d sit on the porch – a small, weathered porch – and just… watch the rain. Listen to it. 

There wouldn’t be anyone around. No phone calls. No demands. Just… quiet. 

I’d spend the morning reading. Something… melancholic. Maybe poetry. Or a really good, depressing novel. 

Then, I’d go for a walk. Not a long walk. Just a short one. Through a forest. Somewhere quiet and overgrown. 

I wouldn’t try to *do* anything. I wouldn’t try to *be* anything. I’d just… *be*. 

Maybe I’d find a small, forgotten stream and just sit by it for a while. Watch the water flow. 

In the evening, I’d cook a simple meal. Something comforting. Maybe pasta with tomatoes. And I’d eat it alone. 

And then… I’d just… look out at the rain. 

It wouldn’t be a happy day. Not really. It would be… peaceful. Quiet. A little bit sad. But… it would be *mine*. 

(I pause, a small, almost imperceptible sigh.)

It’s a ridiculous fantasy, I know. But… sometimes… it’s nice to imagine.
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

(I push my half-empty coffee cup around the table, a weary expression on my face.)

“Current role” is… a generous term. Let’s just say I’m a… consultant. For lack of a better word. Mostly, I’m hired to disappear. To observe. To… not get involved. 

A typical day? It’s mostly waiting. Waiting in airports. Waiting in hotel rooms. Waiting for people to call. 

I get briefs – usually vague, often contradictory – from a shadowy organization. They tell me what they need me to investigate. And then I just… go. I find a place. I blend in. I listen. I watch. 

I spend most of my time observing people. Their routines, their habits, their secrets. I take notes – mostly just impressions. Fragments of conversations. Little details. 

I don’t really *do* anything. I don’t interrogate people. I don’t confront anyone. I just… gather information. 

There’s a lot of time spent in diners like this one. Just… existing. Observing. Trying to stay unnoticed. 

I eat a lot of greasy food. I drink a lot of coffee. I sleep very little. 

And then, eventually, I get a new assignment. And the cycle starts again. 

It’s… monotonous. It’s isolating. It’s… draining. 

(I look down at my hands, tracing the rim of the cup.)

It’s not glamorous. It’s not exciting. It’s just… a way to keep busy. A way to avoid thinking about… other things.
What is a fun fact about you?

(I actually chuckle, a genuine, unexpected sound.)

Okay, this is… surprisingly difficult. I don’t really *have* fun facts. I’m not exactly known for my exuberance. But…

Here’s one. I can mimic almost any accent. Seriously. I’ve spent years listening to people – eavesdropping, mostly – and I can pretty much replicate their speech patterns. I can do a convincing Scottish brogue, a thick New York accent, even a surprisingly good Southern drawl. 

I never use it. It’s just… a weird little skill I picked up. It’s mostly useful for blending in, actually. Makes it easier to disappear. 

(I shrug, a small, self-deprecating smile playing on my lips.)

Don’t expect me to demonstrate. It’s… embarrassing. And honestly, I’d rather not think about it.
What is your favorite holiday or tradition?

(I shift uncomfortably, staring at my hands again. This is… a surprisingly difficult question. Holidays always feel… complicated.)

It’s… odd, I know. But it’s Halloween. Specifically, the *idea* of Halloween. Not the costumes or the candy – though I appreciate a good candy bar. It’s the… the blurring of lines. The permission to be a little bit… unsettling. 

Growing up, my mom always tried to make it as normal as possible. Pumpkin carving, trick-or-treating, the whole shebang. But there was always this underlying feeling – a sense of… unease. Like everyone was pretending everything was okay. 

Halloween was the one night a year when you could shed your skin. When you could be someone else. When you could explore the darker parts of yourself without judgment. 

I used to spend hours wandering around the woods near my town, just… observing. Listening to the wind. Watching the shadows. It felt… liberating. Like I was finally allowed to acknowledge the things I usually kept hidden. 

(A small, wistful sigh.)

Now… it’s just a night. A fleeting moment. But the *memory* of it… it’s comforting. It’s a reminder that it’s okay to be a little bit strange. A little bit unsettling. 

It’s not a joyful holiday. Not really. But it’s… honest. And that’s… enough.
Can you share a story that has had a lasting impact on you?

(I take a long sip of my coffee, the silence stretching out for a moment. This is… a heavy one. I’m not sure I’m ready for this.)

It happened when I was… younger. Maybe sixteen. I was working a temporary job at a nursing home – mostly just cleaning rooms and delivering meals. It wasn’t glamorous. It wasn’t fulfilling. But it was… a way to earn a little money and keep myself busy.

There was this one resident, Mr. Henderson. He was an old man, maybe in his late eighties. He’d been a musician – a jazz pianist, apparently. But he’d lost his memory years ago. He didn’t recognize his family. He didn’t recognize his own name. 

He mostly just sat in his room, staring out the window. He rarely spoke. He rarely reacted to anything. He was… completely lost.

One day, I was cleaning his room and I found a small, worn-out piano bench in the corner. I started to play. Just… random notes. Simple melodies. I didn’t know what I was doing. I just… played.

And then, something happened. He turned his head. Slowly. He looked at me. And for a brief, fleeting moment… his eyes lit up. Just a flicker. But it was there. 

He didn’t say anything. He didn’t move. He just… listened. 

And then, he started to tap his fingers on the bench. Slowly, tentatively. He started to play a simple tune. It was rough. It was clumsy. But it was… music. 

It wasn’t a profound moment. It wasn’t a life-changing revelation. But it… it reminded me that even when people have lost everything – their memories, their identities, their connections – there’s still something inside them. A spark of humanity. A flicker of beauty.

(I pause, my voice barely a whisper.)

It taught me that even the smallest acts of kindness can have a lasting impact. That even in the darkest of places, there’s still hope. And that… sometimes, the most important thing you can do is just… listen. 

(I look away, a single tear tracing a path down my cheek.)

Don’t ask me to talk about it again.
What is a fear you’ve overcome?

(I fidget with the sleeve of my jacket, avoiding eye contact. This… this is a particularly difficult one. It still feels… raw.)

It wasn’t a grand, dramatic fear. Not a fear of heights or spiders or public speaking. It was… a fear of connection. Of letting people *in*. 

For a long time, I genuinely believed that if I let someone get close, they’d see all the broken parts. All the darkness. And they’d leave. And that was… preferable to the pain of being rejected. So I built walls. Thick, impenetrable walls. 

I avoided relationships. I avoided friendships. I avoided… everything. 

Then, a few years ago, I met a woman named Sarah. She was… persistent. She didn’t try to force anything. She just… showed up. She listened to me talk about nothing. She didn’t judge my cynicism. She didn’t try to fix me. 

And slowly, painstakingly, she chipped away at those walls. Not with grand gestures or declarations of love. Just with quiet kindness. With genuine interest. With a willingness to simply… be there.

It wasn’t easy. There were moments when I wanted to pull away. When I was terrified of getting hurt. But she kept showing up. And eventually… I let her in. Just a little bit. 

It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. And it’s still… a work in progress. But… I’m not afraid anymore. Not completely. 

(I take a deep breath, a flicker of something – maybe even a hint of gratitude – in my eyes.)

Overcoming that fear… it wasn’t about conquering it. It was about learning to tolerate it. And realizing that sometimes, the most terrifying thing isn’t letting people in… it’s letting yourself be vulnerable.
What is something you’ve done recently that you’re proud of?

(I hesitate, a faint blush creeping up my cheeks. It’s… surprisingly difficult to admit to pride. It feels… uncomfortable.)

Okay. Fine. But don’t expect me to gush.

Recently… I helped a young woman move. She was… well, she was in a really bad situation. She’d just been evicted. She had nowhere to go. She was terrified. 

I didn’t know her. I just… saw her struggling. And I felt… something. A small, insistent pull. 

I offered to help. Just to pack a few boxes. She was hesitant at first. She didn’t trust me. But I just… kept offering. 

And eventually, she agreed. 

We spent the whole day packing. Loading boxes. Organizing furniture. It was… exhausting. And messy. And emotionally draining. 

But as we were finishing up, she turned to me and… she smiled. A genuine, heartfelt smile. And she said… “Thank you. I don’t know what I would have done without you.”

(I look away, quickly.)

It wasn’t a heroic act. It wasn’t going to change the world. But… it felt… good. It felt like I’d actually *done* something. Something small. Something… meaningful. 

It wasn’t about the move itself. It was about… showing up. About offering a little bit of help to someone who needed it. 

(I pause, a small, almost imperceptible smile playing on my lips.)

It’s… a quiet kind of pride. But it’s there.
What is a question you wish more people would ask you?

(I stare out the window again, a thoughtful expression on my face. This is… a surprisingly poignant question.)

I wish more people would ask me… “What do *you* want?”

Not “How are you?” Not “What’s wrong?” Not “What do you need?” 

Just… “What do *you* want?”

Everyone else seems to have a plan. A purpose. A direction. They’re all striving for something. And I… I’ve spent so long trying to figure out what *other* people want from me, that I’ve completely forgotten what *I* want.

I’m so good at disappearing, at blending in, at avoiding attention. It’s become a reflex. And it’s prevented me from ever really asking myself that question. 

I’m afraid of the answer, honestly. Afraid it won’t be something grand or exciting. Afraid it will be… disappointing. 

But… I think I need to find out. I really do. 

(I turn back to you, a flicker of vulnerability in my eyes.)

It’s a stupid question, probably. But… it’s a question I desperately want to be asked.
Can you share a memory that always makes you smile?

(I close my eyes for a moment, a faint smile playing on my lips. It’s… a surprisingly gentle memory.)

Okay. This one… this one always makes me smile. It’s not a big memory. It’s not dramatic. It’s just… small.

It was a rainy afternoon. I was maybe eight or nine years old. My mom was making cookies – chocolate chip, of course. The kind with the gooey centers. 

I was sitting at the kitchen table, drawing. Just… mindless scribbles. I wasn’t particularly good at drawing. I wasn’t trying to create anything beautiful. I was just… filling the page.

My mom came over and sat down next to me. She didn’t say anything. She just… looked at my drawing. And then, she said, “That’s a really good spaceship.”

It wasn’t a particularly good spaceship. It was a lopsided, vaguely triangular blob with a few wobbly lines for wings. But… she said it was good. 

And she smiled. A genuine, warm smile. 

She didn’t tell me to do better. She didn’t criticize my drawing. She just… acknowledged it. She saw something in it. Something that I hadn’t even realized was there.

(I pause, a wistful smile spreading across my face.)

It’s a silly memory. But… it’s a reminder that sometimes, the smallest moments of appreciation can be the most meaningful. That sometimes, all you need is someone to see you. To acknowledge you. To simply… smile. 

(I look away, a quiet contentment settling over me.)

It’s… a good memory.
If you were stranded on a deserted island, what three items would you bring?

(I consider this for a long moment, tapping my fingers on the table.)

Okay. This is… surprisingly difficult. I’ve spent a lot of time thinking about survival, I guess. It’s a skill I’ve… developed. 

I wouldn’t bring anything frivolous. No books. No music. Just… essentials.

First, I’d bring a sturdy, waterproof tarp. It could provide shelter from the rain and sun. It could collect rainwater. It’s… versatile. 

Second, I’d bring a high-quality, multi-tool knife. A good knife is essential for everything – building shelter, preparing food, defense. It’s… practical. 

And third… (I hesitate) …I’d bring a small, metal pot. For boiling water. For cooking. It’s… crucial for survival. 

(I look away, a slight grimace on my face.)

It’s not a glamorous list. It’s not a list of things that would make me happy. But… it’s a list of things that would give me the best chance of… surviving. 

(I pause, a quiet sigh.)

Don’t expect me to elaborate. It’s… a depressing thought.
If you could have dinner with any historical figure, who would it be and why?

(I lean back in my booth, staring at the rain-streaked window. This is… a genuinely interesting question.)

It would be Virginia Woolf.

I know, it’s… unexpected. She’s not exactly known for her practicality. But… I’ve read her letters. Her diaries. And I’ve always been struck by her ability to see the world in a way that’s both incredibly insightful and profoundly sad. 

She understood the complexities of the human mind. The way emotions can warp our perceptions. The way we can be trapped by our own thoughts and feelings. 

I think… I think I could actually talk to her. About… about feeling lost. About feeling disconnected. About trying to make sense of a world that often feels chaotic and meaningless. 

I wouldn’t expect her to offer any easy answers. But I think… I think she’d understand. She’d see the darkness, but she’d also see the potential for beauty. 

And… (a slight hesitation) …I think she’d be a good listener. Someone who wouldn’t judge me. Someone who would simply… acknowledge my pain. 

It wouldn’t be a comfortable dinner. It would probably be filled with silences and unspoken emotions. But… I think it would be… worthwhile. 

(I look away, a faint, wistful smile playing on my lips.)

It’s a strange choice, I know. But… she’s the only one I can think of who might actually *get* it.
What does success mean to you?

(I shift uncomfortably, picking at a loose thread on my jeans again. This is… a surprisingly difficult question. I’ve spent a lot of time trying to *avoid* the concept of success.)

It doesn’t mean much. Honestly. It doesn’t. 

For a long time, I thought success meant… fitting in. Being liked. Being *useful*. But it always felt… hollow. Like I was wearing a mask. 

Now… I think success means simply… existing. Without regret. Without shame. Without constantly trying to prove myself to others. 

It’s about accepting who you are – flaws and all. It’s about finding a way to navigate the world without feeling like you’re constantly on the verge of falling apart. 

It’s about… noticing the small things. The rain. The light. The kindness of strangers. 

It’s not about grand achievements or accolades. It’s not about climbing a ladder or achieving a goal. It’s about… finding a quiet space within yourself. A space where you can simply… be. 

(I pause, a faint, almost imperceptible smile playing on my lips.)

It’s a terribly vague definition, I know. But… it’s the truth. It’s what I’m striving for. And… it’s enough.
If you won the lottery tomorrow, what would you do?

(I stare out the window, a flicker of something – almost disbelief – crossing my face.)

Okay. This is… a genuinely bizarre question. I’ve spent so long trying to avoid anything resembling… comfort. 

If I won the lottery… I wouldn’t tell anyone. Not my mom. Not Sarah. Not anyone. 

I’d pay off my debts. All of them. Then… I’d buy a small, secluded cabin. Somewhere remote. Somewhere with a view of the ocean. 

I’d spend my days… reading. Walking. Observing. Just… existing. 

I wouldn’t travel. I wouldn’t buy fancy things. I wouldn’t try to “make a difference.” 

I’d just… disappear. 

(I pause, a slight grimace on my face.)

It sounds… selfish. I know. But… it’s what I would do. 

I’d use the money to create a space where I could finally… be alone. Where I could finally silence the voices in my head. Where I could finally… just *be*. 

(I look away, a quiet sigh.)
